text: Interactive notebooks can make bioinformatics data analyses more transparent, accessible and reusable. However, creating notebooks requires computer programming expertise. Here we introduce BioJupies, a web server that enables automated creation, storage, and deployment of Jupyter Notebooks containing RNA-seq data analyses. Through an intuitive interface, novice users can rapidly generate tailored reports to analyze and visualize their own raw sequencing files, their gene expression tables, or fetch data from >5,500 published studies containing >250,000 preprocessed RNA-seq samples. Generated notebooks have executable code of the entire pipeline, rich narrative text, interactive data visualizations, and differential expression and enrichment analyses. The notebooks are permanently stored in the cloud and made available online through a persistent URL. The notebooks are downloadable, customizable, and can run within a Docker container. By providing an intuitive user interface for notebook generation for RNA-seq data analysis, starting from the raw reads, all the way to a complete interactive and reproducible report, BioJupies is a useful resource for experimental and computational biologists. BioJupies is freely available as a web-based application from: http://biojupies.cloud and as a Chrome extension from the Chrome Web Store.

sections.title: Overview
text: BioJupies allows users to generate customized analysis notebooks from RNA-seq data through an intuitive interface, with no knowledge of coding required.
Generating a notebook requires three steps:

1. Select the data you wish to analyze. You can upload your own RNA-seq data - either as raw FASTQ files or as tables containing gene counts - or search over 8,000 publicly available datasets published in the Gene Expression Omnibus and processed by ARCHS4.

• Add Data Analysis Plugins. After selecting the data, you can choose from over 10 data visualization and analysis plugins which will analyze the RNA-seq dataset and embed interactive results in the resulting notebook.
• Generate your notebook. Once you have selected the tools, you can generate the notebook directly from the BioJupies website. The notebook will be returned to you through a permanent, public URL.

sections.title: Getting Started
text: To start generating your notebook, visit https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/analyze.
First, you will be required to specify the dataset you wish to analyze. Three options are available:
1. Search Published Datasets. By means of a search engine, you can rapidly find and analyze over 8,000 publicly available datasets published in the Gene Expression Omnibus and processed by ARCHS4.
• Upload Your Dataset. BioJupies allows you to upload your own RNA-seq dataset, either as raw FASTQ sequencing files, or as processed gene expression count tables.
• Use an Example Dataset. To learn how to generate notebook, BioJupies also provides an example dataset.

sections.title: Uploading your Data
text: BioJupies allows you to generate customized analysis notebooks by uploading your own RNA-seq datasets.
To upload your data, visit https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/upload.
Data can be uploaded in two formats: <ol>

• FASTQ Files. You can upload raw sequencing data in the .fastq.gz format directly to BioJupies. The web server will align your reads to the selected reference genome and generate a notebook from the estimated gene counts. For more information about uploading FASTQ files, click here.

• Gene Count Tables. If you already performed sequence alignment, you can upload text files containing raw gene counts. Uploaded files must have gene symbols on rows and samples on columns. For more information about uploading gene counts, click here.
Once you have uploaded your data, proceed to Adding Analysis Plugins.

sections.title: Searching Published Data
text: In addition to uploading your data, BioJupies users can also analyze over 8,000 publicly available datasets published in the Gene Expression Omnibus and processed by ARCHS4.
To search the pre-processed RNA-seq datasets indexed by BioJupies, visit https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/analyze/search.

You can find datasets relevant to your interests by using a text-based search engine, sort results by date of publication, or filter them by selecting the organism or the number of samples contained within the dataset.
The More Info buttons allows you to access a detailed description of the dataset, as well as a link to its landing page on the Gene Expression Omnibus.
Once you have identified the desired dataset, click on Analyze to proceed to the next step.

sections.title: Adding Analysis Plugins
text: Once you have selected or uploaded a dataset to BioJupies, you can add one or more RNA-seq analysis plugins using the interface shown below. The selected plugins will analyze the dataset and embed interactive plots and visualizations in the resulting notebook.
BioJupies currently supports a variety of RNA-seq data analysis plugins divided in multiple categories, such as Exploratory Data Analysis, Differential Expression Analysis, and Enrichment Analysis.

You can toggle plugins by clicking on the Add or Remove buttons displayed on the right of each card. Additional information regarding each plugin, including links to interactive examples and plugin source code on GitHub, are available by clicking on More Info .
Once you have selected the desired plugins, click on Continue .
If you only selected plugins in the Exploratory Data Analysis category, proceed to Customizing Parameters; otherwise proceed to Selecting Groups.

sections.title: Selecting Groups
text: If you have selected select one or more plugins in the Differential Expression, Enrichment Analysis or Small Molecule Query categories, you are required to specify two groups of samples.
The two groups will be used to perform a differential gene expression analysis and identify a gene expression signature from the data. Groups are defined using the interface below:
You can define the groups of samples in two ways:

1. Specify the group names in the input boxes provided. BioJupies will automatically predict the samples belonging to each group based on the sample metadata provided. You can turn this feature off by clicking on the toggle button displayed beside Predict Groups on the right.
• Use the dropdown buttons to manually select the samples assigned to each group.
In order to improve the statistical validity of the differential expression analysis, BioJupies required that groups contain at least two RNA-seq samples.
Once you have selected the desired groups, click Continue to proceed to the next step.

sections.title: Customizing Parameters
text: After selecting the desired RNA-seq dataset and analysis plugins, you can customize your notebook by changing its title, adding biological tags, or modifying optional parameters for each of the selected plugins.

To customize your analysis, click on the Modify Parameters button displayed on the right of each plugin. BioJupies allows you to optionally modify analysis parameters for a subset of RNA-seq analysis plugins.
Once you have selected the desired settings, click on Generate Notebook to generate the analysis.

sections.title: Generating the Notebook
text: After clicking on Generate Notebook a notebook generation job is submitted to the BioJupies server, and a loader is displayed on the webpage.
The process of notebook generation typically takes between 10 seconds to 3 minutes, depending on the number of plugins selected and on the size of the RNA-seq dataset.

sections.title: Accessing the Notebook
text: Once the notebook has been generated, a link is displayed on the website.
To access the results of your analysis, click on Open Notebook. The notebook is permanently stored on BioJupies and can be accessed at any time through the same persistent, public URL.

BioJupies allows users to generate complete analysis notebooks from their own RNA-seq data through an intuitive web interface, with no knowledge of coding required. To start uploading your data, visit https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/upload.
Data can be uploaded in two formats:

1. Gene Count Tables. If you already performed sequence alignment, you can upload text files containing raw gene counts. Uploaded files must have gene symbols on rows and samples on columns. For more information about uploading gene counts, click here.

• FASTQ Files. You can upload raw sequencing data in the .fastq.gz format directly to BioJupies. The web server will align your reads to the selected reference genome and generate a notebook from the estimated gene counts. For more information about uploading FASTQ files, click here.

sections.title: Uploading Gene Counts
text: If your RNA-seq data has already been processed, you can upload a table file containing of gene expression counts at https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/upload/table.
In order to successfully upload an RNA-seq dataset, your file must have the following format:

• Have gene identifiers on the rows. We recommend using HGNC Gene Symbols to label genes, as several plugins in the Enrichment Analysis and Small Molecule Query categories are optimized for such identifiers. BioJupies also supports other identifier systems such as Ensembl IDs and Entrez IDs; however, please note that plugins in the enrichment analysis and small molecule queries may not return optimal results.
• Have sample names on the columns.

• Have raw gene expression counts as values. While users may successfully upload and analyze normalized RNA-seq datasets (such as FPKM values or log-transformed data) please note that the analysis plugins are currently optimized for analysis of raw gene counts only.
• Be stored in the .txt, .tsv, .csv, .xls or .xlsx format.

sections.title: Uploading FASTQ Files
text: If you have raw RNA-seq data in the FASTQ format, you can upload the files for analysis by BioJupies at https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/upload/reads.
To upload your files, click on and select the FASTQ files you wish to upload. Files must be compressed using gzip and must not individually exceed 5GB in size.
Once you have selected the desired data, click on Upload Files . BioJupies will automatically upload the files for analysis using Elysium.
Upload may take between a minute to over an hour, depending on the size of the files and on the speed of your internet connection.
Once the process is completed, the Continue button is activated and will allow you to proceed to the next step.

sections.title: Launching Alignment Jobs
text: After the FASTQ files have been uploaded, you can configure the alignment process using the interface below:
In order to estimate gene expression, you are required to specify two parameters:
1. The organism from which the RNA-seq samples were generated. This parameter will be used to select the reference genome for alignment using Elysium.
• Whether the FASTQ files were generated using single-end sequencing or paired-end sequencing.
By selecting single-end sequencing, the FASTQ files will be individually aligned to the reference genome and will each return one column in the resulting dataset.
By selecting paired-end sequencing, you will be required to specify which pairs of FASTQ files have been generated from the same biological sample.
The pairs will be used to perform paired alignment and will each return one column in the resulting dataset. Samples can be optionally renamed using the text boxes provided.
Once you have selected the desired alignment settings, click Continue to launch the alignment jobs, then proceed to the next step.

sections.title: Viewing Job Status
text: After the alignment jobs have been launched, you will be redirected to a page displaying the status of the jobs.
Alignment jobs may have four statuses:
1. Waiting. Indicates a queued job, which will be executed when resources are available.
• Submitted. Indicates a job which is currently being performed.
• Completed. Indicates a job which has completed successfully.
• Failed. Indicates a job which has failed.

Most jobs should complete in around 10-15 minutes. BioJupies currently supports concurrent alignment of two jobs at a time. If users requests more than two jobs at the same times, additional jobs will be added to the queue. For more information about the alignment pipeline, visit Elysium.
The alignment jobs will continue running if the user exits the page. The job status will remain accessible from the same unique URL.
Once the alignment jobs have completed, click Continue to proceed to the next step.

sections.title: Adding Sample Metadata
text: Before analyzing your RNA-seq data, BioJupies requires you to add information describing the samples contained in the dataset, such as the experimental group they belong to (e.g. wild type or knock-out, healthy or diseased).
This information can be used to extract knowledge from the data more efficiently in the subsequent downstream analysis steps.
You can add information about your RNA-seq samples in two ways:
1. By manually specifying groups the samples belong to, using the text boxes on the left.

• By uploading a table containing information about the specified samples. The table must have sample names on the rows, and can contain any number of columns specifying different properties of the uploaded samples.
Once you have added the desired information, click Continue to upload your dataset to BioJupies. You can then proceed to Adding Analysis Plugins.
In addition to the web server, BioJupies is also freely available for download as a Google Chrome browser extension.

The Chrome extension enhances the Gene Expression Omnibus (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds) DataSet browser, a popular website and repository which indexes tens of thousands of publicly available datasets published in peer-reviewed journals.

To achieve this, the extension embeds interfaces which allow users to automatically generate notebooks directly from the GEO website. This allows GEO users to take advantage of the BioJupies notebook generation capabilities without having to leave the website, thus maintaining access to its advanced search features.

sections.title: Installing the Extension
text: The Chrome Extension can be installed for free from the Chrome Web Store at the following URL: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/biojupies-generator/picalhhlpcjhonibabfigihelpmpadel.
To install the extension, click on the Add to Chrome button displayed on the web store. Once installed, the BioJupies icon will be displayed on the top right corner of your Chrome window.

sections.title: Searching Data
text: Once the Chrome Extension has been installed, it will be activated on the Gene Expression Omnibus DataSet browser.
The extension adds a button beside each RNA-seq dataset which is available for analysis using BioJupies.
An example is shown below for https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=GSE88741.

By clicking on the button, users can proceed to Adding Analysis Plugins in order to generate a customized Jupyter Notebook from the desired dataset entirely through a user interface, with no knowledge of coding required.

Note: BioJupies currently supports ~8,000 RNA-seq datasets processed by ARCHS4. Since the Gene Expression Omnibus indexes a large number of datasets which have not been generated using RNA-sequencing, many search results will not have a Generate Notebook button.
For a complete list of processed datasets see https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/analyze/search.

sections.title: Adding Analysis Plugins
text: After clicking on the Generate Notebook button, you can add one or more RNA-seq analysis plugins using the interface shown below. The selected plugins will analyze the dataset and embed interactive plots and visualizations in the resulting notebook.
You can toggle plugins by clicking on each card. Plugins highlighted in blue will be added to your notebook. Once you have selected the desired plugins, click on Next .
If you only selected plugins in the Exploratory Data Analysis category, proceed to Customizing Parameters; otherwise proceed to Selecting Groups.

sections.title: Selecting Groups
text: If you have selected select one or more plugins in the Differential Expression, Enrichment Analysis or Small Molecule Query categories, you are required to specify two groups of samples.
The two groups will be used to perform a differential gene expression analysis and identify a gene expression signature from the data. Groups are defined using the interface below:
To define the groups of samples:
1. Select the IDs on the left column to assign samples to Group A.
• Select the IDs on the right column to assign samples to Group B.
• Optionally, name the groups using the text boxes displayed at the bottom of the window.
In order to improve the statistical validity of the differential expression analysis, BioJupies required that groups contain at least three RNA-seq samples.
Once you have selected the desired groups, click Next to proceed to the next step.

sections.title: Customizing Parameters
text: After selecting the desired RNA-seq dataset and analysis plugins, you can customize your notebook by changing its title or modifying optional parameters for each of the selected plugins.
To customize your analysis, click on the button displayed on the right of each plugin name. BioJupies allows you to optionally modify analysis parameters for a subset of RNA-seq analysis plugins.
Once you have selected the desired settings, click on Generate Notebook to generate the analysis.

sections.title: Generating the Notebook
text: After clicking on Generate Notebook a notebook generation job is submitted to the BioJupies server, and a loader is displayed on the window.
The process of notebook generation typically takes between 10 seconds to 3 minutes, depending on the number of plugins selected and on the size of the RNA-seq dataset.

sections.title: Accessing the Notebook
text: Once the notebook has been generated, a link is displayed on the window.
To access the results of your analysis, click on Open Notebook. The notebook is permanently stored on BioJupies and can be accessed at any time through the same persistent, public URL.

sections.title: 5. Using the Chrome Extension
text: Instructions on installing and using the BioJupies Google Chrome extension. For more information see the Chrome Extension section.

sections.title: 6. Reusing Notebooks
text: Overview of how users can download, execute and customize BioJupies Notebooks on their local computer (Mac OS shown). For more information see the Reusing Notebooks section.
BioJupies is currently available as a pre-print on bioRxiv: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2018/06/20/352476
Source code for BioJupies is available at https://github.com/MaayanLab/biojupies under the Apache License 2.0.
Provided gene expression files are available under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
BioJupies is free to use for non-commercial purposes. For commercial use, please contact MSIP.
